reviews.text: A moronic melange of narrative gobbledygook, Venom: The Last Dance wouldn't be worth your time even if it were tap dancing on Marvel's headstone.
reviews.author: Nicholas Bell

reviews.text: Like the previous entries, it's also something of a tonal jumble, part goofy buddy comedy, part po-faced sci-fi tale, with neither passing muster on their own, never mind awkwardly stitched together.
reviews.author: Patrick Cremona

reviews.text: Strike three.
reviews.author: Nathan Chizen

reviews.text: The third and final entry in what has proven to be among the junkiest of all Marvel movie franchises.
reviews.author: Matt Brunson

reviews.text: Kelly [Marcel] peppers the film – particularly the banter between Eddie and the Venom symbiote – with moments that are sweet, funny, unconventional, and even moving
reviews.author: Devansh Sharma

reviews.text: Hardy brilliantly portrays Eddie and Venom as they meld into one, creating a dynamic duo that makes the Venom films engaging and entertaining to watch.
reviews.author: Allison Rose

reviews.text: ... a final film in the "Venom" trilogy whose ambitions fail to deliver the excitement or thrills of the prior two installments while also introducing a threat to nowhere, resulting in more tedium than entertainment.
reviews.author: Douglas Davidson

reviews.text: The film may feature the same intriguing main characters, who provide it with some entertainment value, but it also suffers from notable problems with its antagonist, supporting characters, and overall storyline.
reviews.author: Jeff Beck

reviews.text: It’s all so pointlessly silly, and loud, so so very loud, and very much aware of how silly and loud it is, because that seems to be the desperately stupid goal of these films.
reviews.author: John Serba

reviews.text: The Venom series can’t think in more imaginative terms than strategic deployment: Maybe if Hardy goes for it even harder, the greater Marvel universe will have no choice but to bend back in our direction!
reviews.author: Jesse Hassenger

reviews.text: The Venom series began as a lazy, cynical IP cash-in born from the wrongheaded notion that moviegoers want cinematic universes and superheroes in the abstract. It is now oddly innocent and specific, even compared to the brand it tried to emulate.
reviews.author: Scott Mendelson

reviews.text: As far as road trip tales go, “Venom: The Last Dance” finds a steady route.
reviews.author: Rick Bentley

reviews.text: Playing Eddie and Venom, Tom Hardy wrings a surprising amount of sentiment from a performance that essentially involves talking to himself, and the film derives its tender tone from the notion that this partnership might finally have to come to an end.
reviews.author: Gayle Sequeira

reviews.text: An absolute car crash of a film. That's not to say that bits of it aren't entertaining... if you throw enough poop at the wall, then some of it it's gonna stick.
reviews.author: Mark Kermode

reviews.text: Marcel does understand that humour is the key to engaging with this character, the "buddy comedy" interplay between Eddie and Venom, and she gives the film a light touch with plenty of charming moments.
reviews.author: Cris Kennedy

reviews.text: So it's entirely possible that this movie felt like a letdown because the first two were decent and Tom Hardy is delightful but everybody involved just ran out of steam and gave up and decided to bum everybody out.
reviews.author: Nick Bhasin

reviews.text: The tired dynamic between Eddie and Venom, underdeveloped new characters, and a weak central antagonist make Venom: The Last Dance the most uninspired entry in the series.
reviews.author: Jason Escamilla

reviews.text: If this is truly the last we’ll see of this iteration of Venom, then good riddance.
reviews.author: Kip Mooney

reviews.text: “Venom: The Last Dance” is like a graveyard for good actors’ spirits to die. Hardy, who is one of the greats, is just phoning it in and looks as if he is in this film under great duress.
reviews.author: Sarah Vincent

reviews.text: The studio should pay you [the viewer] to watch this horrible film. It's a complete waste of time. This was just a mess of a movie. Thank goodness it's "the last dance."
reviews.author: Michael Cook

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance is choppy and nonsensical and isn’t even enjoyable as a hate watch. Sony even has the nerve to threaten the audience with a continuation of the worn-out series, and no one wants that.
reviews.author: MontiLee Stormer

reviews.text: Worst interior monologue ever -- I hope it is the last dance.
reviews.author: Wade Major

reviews.text: Basically, I like these movies more than I actually respect them.
reviews.author: Jared Rasic

reviews.text: Hardy’s endearingly oblong central performance and the way he vibes with his alien pal make all of these compulsively watchable when they’re on screen.
reviews.author: Cory Woodroof

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance was very enjoyable and kind of sweet for a movie where a monster eats people’s heads. Basically, the movie is grounded in human emotion and characterization rather than spectacle which is why it is successful for me.
reviews.author: Dolores Quintana

reviews.text: The Last Dance is certainly an improvement on Let There Be Carnage, though, and probably the best of the trilogy.
reviews.author: Ian Bunting

reviews.text: The high points are fun, comical and often violent, ranging from amusing one-liners to well-deserved beat downs... However, there are major lulls in which the jokes fall flat and Eddie’s constant trepidation is annoying
reviews.author: Sarah Gopaul

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance sputters to an unsatisfying conclusion that will likely leave fans of the series wishing for something more. Tom Hardy may not quite be phoning it in, but it's clear the fire has gone. Please let this be the final dance. Please.
reviews.author: Matt Hudson

reviews.text: A spectacular film... with a sentimental, emotional, and dramatic touch that was not expected in this departure(?) of the Lethal Protector. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fausto Fernandez

reviews.text: While there is some fun to be had (in particular in the 3rd act), the story is a mess.  Three movies into this trilogy, it's disappointing they never figured out how to craft film which is both fun and coherent.
reviews.author: Sean Chandler

reviews.text: Marcel’s film has a ton of potential in a cast that’s clearly game and centered on a terrifically entertaining performance from Hardy. When it’s having fun, “The Last Dance” is infectiously delightful, but those moments are too far and few in between.
reviews.author: Rob Dean

reviews.text: Tom Hardy clearly has a blast as Eddie/Venom and this final installment to the VENOM trilogy is hilarious and exactly what you would expect from a Venom film. The Eddie/Venom casino scene has me rolling!
reviews.author: Lauren Veneziani

reviews.text: It is forced, and too formulaic to generate any real emotion. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ruben Peralta Rigaud

reviews.text: "The most romantic trilogy in cinema since the Before trilogy."
reviews.author: Gabriela Meza

reviews.text: Venom The Last Dance is a chaotic road trip of subplots and forgettable characters, stuck in a mid-2000s comic book vibe. Eddie and Venom’s bromance is the only highlight, but everything else feels random, abrupt, and half-hearted.
reviews.author: John Flickinger

reviews.text:
Undoubtedly the weakest of the trilogy. Tom Hardy does his best with a poor script but ultimately the film couldn’t decide between being a finale or a trailer for future franchises.

It’s a fun popcorn movie but after a full trilogy, audiences wants more.
reviews.author: Sheraz Farooqi

reviews.text: Whether this Venom movie is irritating and inconsequential or entertaining and interesting depends entirely on audience expectations. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Juanma Fernández París

reviews.text: I watch these movies to laugh. How can they not understand that? Unfortunately laughs are few and far between in Venom: The Last Dance.
reviews.author: Rachel Wagner

reviews.text: This franchise just wouldn't work without Tom Hardy. This movie really drags whenever Eddie and/or Venom is not on screen. Overall this Venom swan song is a whirlwind of crazy fun.
reviews.author: Ruth Maramis

reviews.text: The vaudeville-style quirky banter between Venom and Eddie is arguably the best it's been in this unlikely trilogy. However, it's also the film's lone consistent redeeming element.
reviews.author: Edwin Arnaudin

reviews.text: The Eddie / Venom dynamic is once again hilarious, but this time it also comes with an existential crisis.
reviews.author: JD Duran

reviews.text: As the closing chapter of this Venom trilogy, The Last Dance falters in its steps but ultimately manages to shuffle to the end of its swan song serviceably.
reviews.author: Matt Fernandez

reviews.text: The third and last film in the awful Marvel movie trilogy about a helmet-headed alien with scary teeth and a large tongue.
reviews.author: Dennis Schwartz

reviews.text: Keep moving, nothing new to see here.
reviews.author: Jackie K. Cooper

reviews.text: The third and supposedly final entry in this "superhero" series is more of the same: endless exposition, overreliance on visual effects and explosions, and no real characters or story.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: Ultimately, Venom: The Last Dance is a fun-filled ride that perfectly balances humour and action, thanks to Kelly Marcel’s directorial prowess and Tom Hardy’s magnetic performance.
reviews.author: Devesh Sharma

reviews.text: Sadly, the film stumbles through a series of missteps, leaving even die-hard fans of the franchise wondering if this final entry is more of a farewell dance or a half-hearted shuffle.
reviews.author: Troy Ribeiro

reviews.text: There's plenty of satisfying set pieces here and a great soundtrack.
reviews.author: Laura Stott

reviews.text: It’s Tom Hardy show and as expected he hits the ball out of the park with his dual role of defamed journalist Eddie Brock and his alien alter-ego Venom.
reviews.author: Ganesh Aaglave

reviews.text: This is a flawed, but enjoyable movie despite its inconsistencies. It is full of humanity and good-natured fun. There are some very nice moments between Eddie and Mrs. Chen, as well as between Eddie and Martin's young son, Leaf.
reviews.author: Robert Roten

reviews.text: Despite featuring a Venom horse and Venom dancing with Mrs Chen to ABBA, this concluding instalment disappointingly shies away from what’s made the franchise the surprise hit for Sony – the kooky but surprisingly endearing Eddie Brock/Venom dynamic.
reviews.author: Nicola Austin

reviews.text: The Last Dance is entertaining because it’s chaotic and this bizarre bromance that is way more impactful than it should be is legitimately just one guy that enjoys making silly movies that barely make sense.
reviews.author: Chris Sawin

reviews.text: ...mostly intolerable...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: The action meant nothing, the villain meant nothing to me...
reviews.author: Tony Baker

reviews.text: Ultimately, the set pieces in [Venom: The Last Dance] matter far less than the central, possibly only, reason to watch any entry in the Venom series: Tom Hardy as the put-upon, losing-at-life ex-journalist and his permanent houseguest.
reviews.author: Mel Valentin

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance is not some great comic book superhero masterpiece, and neither were the first two pieces of this trilogy. But Hardy and Marcel had a game plan and they steadfastly followed it all the way to the end. I respect that.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: The comedy is below par, the set-pieces distinctly unmemorable and the plot holes are gaping.
reviews.author: Larushka Ivan-Zadeh

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance is a sincere finale to one of the greatest love stories ever told: an ex-journalist and his gooey glutinous alien boyfriend.
reviews.author: Jillian Chilingerian

reviews.text: The trilogy has always featured some great actors and few inspired ideas, mostly buried under a mess of generic plotting and seemingly rushed special effects. If The Last Dance is the last we see the character, then he's going out exactly as he came in.
reviews.author: Graeme Tuckett

reviews.text: The story advances without much conviction through a trajectory that wastes formulas, jokes, and even lines that are well-known from previous experiences in this same universe. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Marcelo Stiletano

reviews.text: Billed as the final instalment of the Venom trilogy and feels like a contractual obligation for nearly everyone concerned.
reviews.author: Jake Wilson

reviews.text: While the antihero deserved much more than this conclusion that does not commit to epicness-turned-into-content or a '90s buddy movie, [Venom: The Last Dance] has details that deserve some attention. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Randy Meeks

reviews.text: The third and final episode in the Venom saga issues a third and final reminder that the world never really needed a Venom saga in the first place.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: If you can’t enjoy Tom Hardy sitting in stony silence while his alien lover croons along joyfully to Space Oddity inside his head, then I don’t know what to tell you.
reviews.author: Tom Beasley

reviews.text: Overloaded with cartoonish CGI action scenes and non-stop patter, this is never less than entertaining – though it’s also pretty disposable.
reviews.author: Kim Newman

reviews.text: The Last Dance remains steadfast in the franchise’s commitment to storytelling that, like a pot of water that never quite hits boiling point, is neither so-bad-it’s-good nor so bad it’s raucously entertaining, even if only unintentionally so.
reviews.author: Sarah-Tai Black

reviews.text: This movie is Eddie and Venom’s story. Take out all the extra plot and characters and it is still about these two needing each other.
reviews.author: Rachel Leishman

reviews.text: An adequate goodbye to a fun trilogy that dared to have fun before the world building got too serious.
reviews.author: KT Mahe

reviews.text: A missed opportunity for a great send-off. Too many new elements made it feel like a reset instead of a finale. Still fun, but lacked the punch I hoped for.
reviews.author: Oti

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance is the agonizing death rattle for what might be the most irritating series of superhero movies within the past 25 years, but it does contain one tolerable, even slightly amusing, stretch
reviews.author: Robert Kojder

reviews.text: Venom ran out of naphtha and gasoline in its second outing. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Pablo O. Scholz

reviews.text: Funny and warm, even if elements are pasted together without much regard for logic. Indeed, the narrative relies far too heavily on coincidence.
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: There is some fun along the way, such as the moment from the promotional footage in which Venom overtakes a horse to super-charge it, but there’s nothing special to be found in The Last Dance.
reviews.author: Mark Meszoros

reviews.text: The film is, for the most part, a litany of bad, embarrassing or lowest-common-denominator choices, and it’s unsurprising that the love interest from previous films, Michelle Williams, has opted to cut and run with this new one.
reviews.author: David Jenkins

reviews.text: It's more of the same, just more uninspired. It feels like a forced ending, with a tone that vacillates between sentimental and ridiculous, and that never manages to develop its ideas well, even if most of them are unoriginal. Full review in Spanish.
reviews.author: Sebastian Zavala Kahn

reviews.text: It relies so little on real actors doing real acting that it might as well be animated. It’s loud, chaotic, and not the least bit interesting.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance is an improvement over the previous two movies. I finally accept Eddie Brock and Venom as a comedy duo.
reviews.author: Korey Coleman

reviews.text: In typical Sony/Marvel fashion, I got another horrendous mess. Also in typical Sony/Marvel fashion, I had a blast.
reviews.author: Rendy Jones

reviews.text: The film offers a heartfelt farewell to the franchise, while unexpectedly breathing new life into it — resulting in an uneven but mostly enjoyable experience.
reviews.author: Joseph Garcia

reviews.text: Venom is a visually interesting creation, with his Alien knock-off, knife-toothed predator’s head belied by big, wet eyes, but the weightless digital punch-ups feel unreal, and being asked to shed a tear for the head-chomping lug is too much.
reviews.author: Nick Hasted

reviews.text: In the end, Venom: The Last Dance is just another comic book movie.
reviews.author: Tori Preston

reviews.text: Hardy is a highlight, playing Eddie as a man who has had more than enough of the party that's raging in his head, but Kelly Marcel's film is a sloppy, incoherent let-down.
reviews.author: Wendy Ide

reviews.text: As Last Dances go, then, it's less an impeccably choreographed waltz than a bizarre bit of freestyle where the most fun part is watching the dancer fall all over himself. Which is not without its appeal, but it's not enough to sustain it for two hours.
reviews.author: Ilan Preskovsky

reviews.text: Alas, there are too many competing energies here to let the movie breathe.
reviews.author: Nick Johnston

reviews.text: When Venom: The Last Dance leans into the weirdness and steps away from standard plot points, it pushes the envelope of the genre in an unexpected direction. More of that, please.
reviews.author: Tim Brennan

reviews.text: The good news is that it’s energetic and fun.
reviews.author: Abbie Bernstein

reviews.text: It's a popcorn movie by every definition of a popcorn movie at every level.
reviews.author: Shawn Edwards

reviews.text: Tom Hardy and Kelly Marcel achieve the perfect symbiosis, making Venom 3: The Last Dance an intense and emotional closing of the trilogy for the lethal protector. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Victor Recinos

reviews.text: “Venom” as a franchise works as a comic book cousin of “Lethal Weapon” or any other popular series featuring an entertaining, mismatched duo.
reviews.author: Alci Rengifo

reviews.text: The weakest of the franchise by virtue of it having to do the most franchise stuff. And yet, the central concept, of Tom Hardy having an alien imaginary friend who makes him do cool stuff, still plays.
reviews.author: Vincent Mancini

reviews.text: If you didn’t like the first two movies, you won’t feel differently about this. But if these movies scratch your guilty pleasure brain like me, then have at it.
reviews.author: Jonathan Sim

reviews.text: The Last Dance is cheesy, yet it showcases the relationship between our title character and his symbiote beautifully. The biggest mishap is the jumbled mess of a story, as it nonsensically jumps around for 90 minutes straight.
reviews.author: Austin Burke

reviews.text: Nothing but random scenes which go nowhere but eat up screen time allowing for a technically feature length film to be attached to the appropriate numeral of related derivations to separate suckers from their money.
reviews.author: Joshua Starnes

reviews.text: A surprisingly good cast – including Tom Hardy, Juno Temple, and Chewitel Ejiofor – struggle to carry the silly script, which feels like it was written by a group of hyperactive children on a diet of sugar cereal and Pixy Stix.
reviews.author: Kevin Carr

reviews.text: The movie navigates through a thematic, narrative, and visual mediocrity that isn't bothersome but is not too surprising either. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Diego Batlle

reviews.text: It’s commendable that Hardy and co. managed to serve up three goofy takes on an inherently absurd character that remained emotionally honest right up until the very end
reviews.author: Evan Dossey

reviews.text: Hardy, Marcel and co. seem to genuinely love these characters. It's unfortunate that the remaining majority of the runtime is a headache and a half, but as Marvel movies at large begin to wane in quality and cultural relevance, we'll take what we can get.
reviews.author: Siddhant Adlakha

reviews.text: What could have been a fascinating exploration of a complex and dangerous antihero ends up being an unintentional comedy that, by trying to do too much, accomplishes too little. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Miguel Calabria

reviews.text: Boarding the long-steamless train of the infamous SSU, 'Venom: The Last Dance' spreads the franchise's desperate joylessness to a nauseating degree.
reviews.author: Charlotte Simmons

reviews.text: Though the concept itself is running out of gas, and it would be nice to free up Hardy to do other things, it’s a fitting sendoff for the cheeky alien with the thousand-watt grin.
reviews.author: Katie Walsh

reviews.text: Expect less and never be disappointed.
reviews.author: Sarah Marrs

reviews.text: The bizarre choices made in several departments from the storytelling to the performances have effectively turned the once-cool character into the movie equivalent of Elon Musk repeatedly jumping on the stage at a Trump rally.
reviews.author: Jack Martin

reviews.text: It still may muster up enough to satisfy the Venom die-hards (assuming they exist). But most everyone else will just be happy the series has come to an end.
reviews.author: Keith Garlington

reviews.text: …audiences will be glad to see the back of this adolescent, childish sequence of films; when the highlight of a trilogy turns out to be a clip from another movie, it’s time to pack up and go home; the Venom franchise is thankfully Knull-and-void….
reviews.author: Eddie Harrison

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance channels a forgotten '90s trilogy vibe, delivering laughs and action but often tipping into absurdity.
reviews.author: Nelson Acosta

reviews.text: The film is another poorly thought-out attempt by Sony to create the studio's own version of the MCU, using Spider-Man family characters who cannot and will not interact with Spider-Man on the big screen.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Harris

reviews.text: This is the weakest of the three, mostly because it has too many action set pieces and not as much alone time for our favorite dysfunctional couple.
reviews.author: Marya E. Gates

reviews.text: The low-stakes adventure has nowhere to go except into the mandated comic-book action climax. It is a confusion of slimy tentacled computer-effects as Eddie/Venom, plus every character new and recurring...
reviews.author: Whang Yee Ling

reviews.text: Your enjoyment of the film may depend on how much you ship SymBrock, and how much that can carry through.
reviews.author: Paul Klein

reviews.text: In a franchise full of Spider-Man wannabes, the one most associated with Spidey ended up being the most successful because it was about a true connection rather than tenuous connections between multiversal IP.
reviews.author: James Grebey

reviews.text: So bad that it seems to be done on purpose. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Luis Martínez

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance continues the tradition of being better than the previous one. It’s a rollicking adventure that’s not only a great wrap up to these characters, but it’s simply good old fashioned entertainment for entertainment’s sake.
reviews.author: Damond Fudge

reviews.text: The Last Dance doesn’t exactly deliver on the iffy but intriguing comic madness Sony has been teasing, it does bring this gooey, gory bit of ridiculous adaptation to a fitting end.
reviews.author: Charles Pulliam-Moore

reviews.text: “Venom: The Last Dance” is the best of the trilogy. But that's not saying much, in a saga that tends toward the mediocre and boring all too often. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Aglaia Berlutti

reviews.text: “The Last Dance” is a terribly uneven mix of PG-13 comic book violence and cutesy characterizations that often fall utterly flat.
reviews.author: Jonathan W. Hickman

reviews.text: Like its predecessors, Venom: The Last Dance isn’t particularly good; also like its predecessors, however, it’s strangely watchable.
reviews.author: Sonny Bunch

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance attempts to provide a final stamp on this goofy saga, but only leaves us confused with bad jokes, lackluster CGI, and a mindless plot.
reviews.author: Leo Brady

reviews.text: This sort-of concluding chapter to the Venom trilogy skates by on Tom Hardy's charm, with things simply happening, one after another, generating zero suspense.
reviews.author: Dylan Roth

reviews.text: A supremely silly thing that can in no way be regarded as anything but objectively bad but which nevertheless is just idiosyncratic and amusing enough to offer viewers a genuinely decent time.
reviews.author: Matt Lynch

reviews.text: I think I’m giving [the filmmakers] credit, then, by ascribing the film’s problems to apathy. If it’s not apathy, it’s incompetence.
reviews.author: Sean Collier

reviews.text: It’s not big or clever but it is enjoyable
reviews.author: Lou Thomas

reviews.text: As a popcorn flick where you park your brain and enjoy watching Venom bite off people’s heads for an hour and forty minutes, it’s dumb fun
reviews.author: Joe Lipsett

reviews.text: The endless space-monster battles suggest, more than anything else, digital cockroach frenzies.
reviews.author: Kurt Loder

reviews.text: An appropriately awful finale to one of the worst movie trilogies ever.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: Sure, there’s a ton of PG-13 violence and lots of explosions, but their last dance is still more of an affectionate tango than a hardcore mosh.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: Honestly, I’d rather watch Eddie and Venom dicker over pizza toppings than team up for something as banal as saving the planet.
reviews.author: Amy Nicholson

reviews.text: “The Last Dance” doesn’t feel like a substantive end to an overall trilogy- it often flaunts that it’s not the end of the story.  At least we know humans and aliens can co-exist!
reviews.author: Murjani Rawls

reviews.text: For a movie claiming to be the “final” installment, it concludes with a whimper, failing to raise the stakes enough to make you care about the fate of the main character and those around him.
reviews.author: Nate Adams

reviews.text: Follows suit with the previous two films, embracing the ridiculous and silly, while also throwing in quite a bit of heart. It does not take itself seriously, which makes for a fun watch.
reviews.author: Tessa Smith

reviews.text: The final chapter in the story of Eddie Brock (Tom Hardy) and his alien symbiote is also the worst, little more than a long chase scene as alien and human forces try to capture Venom.
reviews.author: Chris Knight

reviews.text: The film leans heavily into fan service, and the bromance between Eddie and Venom is enjoyable. However, in terms of overall engagement and thrill, it's likely a one-time watch.
reviews.author: Dhaval Roy

reviews.text: Once again a character that should be foreboding and menacing is turned into a 3 Stooges sidekick. There's so many thin plotlines that don't amount to much, and we get a CGI vomit fest in the final act. Bravo.
reviews.author: Lee McCoy

reviews.text: More an interspecies bromance comedy than end of the world movie, Venom: The Last Dance is a frat party of a film, complete with swearing, booze, dancing and a disregard for the rules (in this case, the rules of storytelling).
reviews.author: Richard Crouse

reviews.text: When Hardy is on screen, Venom: The Last Dance is a bad movie, but at least a palatable one. Whenever he’s not, it’s positively unbearable.
reviews.author: Andrew Parker

reviews.text: For what’s meant to be Hardy’s swan song, the offering doesn’t carry the proper weight of finality. Or any big laughs.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: Its foundation is still comic-book, but its heart is a goofy buddy-movie, with Eddie (Hardy) happy to call on his wisecracking “friend” Venom to kick bad-guy butt and just to keep him company.
reviews.author: Nell Minow

reviews.text: The Last Dance is a better creation that’s painless to sit through.
reviews.author: Lisa Laman

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance is so buried under its moving parts that it can’t do justice to any of them, in spite of Marcel’s efforts.
reviews.author: Susana Polo

reviews.text: Somehow, The Last Dance is simultaneously 20 minutes too long for the script they have and 30 minutes too short for the story they want to tell.
reviews.author: Richard Whittaker

reviews.text: The ending means to stir our emotions, and it does inspire one: relief that it’s over.
reviews.author: Johnny Oleksinski

reviews.text: The third installment is about as good as the previous two entries in the franchise; it’s as generic as the first one, and as cartoony as the second. Venom: The Last Dance is not good, but I had a blast watching it.
reviews.author: Edgar Ortega

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance is perhaps not as strong as the previous entry, but it keeps its focus on the best parts (Tom Hardy's incredible performance), and at least at under 2 hours, it does not overstay its welcome, which is refreshing.
reviews.author: Shelagh Rowan-Legg

reviews.text: Spins its wheels for the first hour, but has a pretty good last half hour.
reviews.author: Chris Bumbray

reviews.text: One would think "The Last Dance" implies a big climax. Instead, we get a flaccid, predictable romp that seems to only exist to set up a fourth installment.
reviews.author: Joseph Robinson

reviews.text: One can feel the sense of grudging obligation behind every element of Venom: The Last Dance.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance will have you laughing and cheering out loud while also fighting boredom in a strained narrative that feels much longer than its runtime. The third and supposedly final installment can best be described as uneven.
reviews.author: Julian Roman

reviews.text: There’s enough of the Eddie/Venom dynamic to keep fans engaged, but the movie’s insistence on prioritizing plot-heavy exposition and unnecessary subplots holds it back from being the chaotic, joyful mess it could have been.
reviews.author: Brent Hankins

reviews.text: Venom 3 rivals Joker 2 for worst superhero movie of all time.
reviews.author: Howard Waldstein

reviews.text: It's a chaotic, often incoherent plot that makes poor use of elements from the previous movies as well as mythology from Marvel's recent Venom comic books.
reviews.author: Josh Bell

reviews.text: Too moronic for it to earn the emotional weight it clearly wants to project.
reviews.author: Peter Gray

reviews.text: Tom Hardy's batshit crazy dual performance keeps being the bright spot of the franchise. The rest? Leaves much to be desired for a finale - Knull included. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fico Cangiano

reviews.text: Everything looks and sounds the same in what is a stamped-out popcorn-pushing time killer. It’s passable, but the creature designs look too familiar while the frenetic action scenes feature an edit about once every second, which are tough on the glazzies.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: An asinine, exhausting and tedious mess with choppy editing and not nearly enough laughs or thrills.
reviews.author: Avi Offer

reviews.text: ... an overstuffed yet somehow stunningly simplistic flick that feels more like an excuse to execute stupid but cool ideas ...
reviews.author: Anthony O'Connor

reviews.text: I kept rooting for the surprisingly lifeless “The Last Dance” to pull way back on its save-the-world plot (and its CGI) and lean more into its most potent effect: Hardy’s split-personality double act.
reviews.author: Jake Coyle

reviews.text: In a series where messiness is encouraged, Venom: The Last Dance is unforgivably sloppy.
reviews.author: Abby Olcese

reviews.text: Could never accept such a goofy/silly character. Venom The Last Dance is a fun, wild, hot mess. There's too much plot that's never explained. Events just happen randomly with no payoff, with a big action scene towards the end.
reviews.author: Brandon Avery

reviews.text: Sony faceplants again with “Venom: The Last Dance,” a disposable lark arguably more dull than horrible but so excruciatingly tedious it circles back to atrocious.
reviews.author: Rodrigo Perez

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance is so sloppily made and uninteresting, it's an example of a sequel that doesn't need to exist. Talented cast members are stuck in this dull and predictable comic book movie.
reviews.author: Carla Hay

reviews.text: The bar has been lowered enough it’s excusable that it’s not very good, either, because at least it has the balls to be off-the-chain nutty, a goopy send-off to the oddest couple in all of Marvel.
reviews.author: Travis Hopson

reviews.text: When it leans hard into the inherent absurdity of its wacky, mismatched buddy antics, “Venom: The Last Dance” can be a total blast. Unfortunately, that doesn’t happen nearly as often as it should.
reviews.author: Christy Lemire

reviews.text: Narrative cinema rarely cares this little about actual narrative, transforming what’s supposed to be the concluding chapter of an ongoing saga into little more than pure sensation — blobs of color, bursts of sound.
reviews.author: Alonso Duralde

reviews.text: Why are all these random concepts drummed up on a whim, with no background, no rules, and no reasons? With such pitiful writing, it’s impossible to take any of the scenarios seriously.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: While Venom: The Last Dance may be weaker than its predecessors (of which 2018’s Venom is the best), it’s still a good time, and you can tell leading man-turned-writer Tom Hardy is too.
reviews.author: Kate Sánchez

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance is the perfect sendoff for Tom Hardy's Eddie Brock and Venom, wrapping up the characters' stories with deliberate care.
reviews.author: Molly Freeman

reviews.text: We’ll miss watching Tom Hardy rock Hawaiian shirts, ride motorcycles, and argue with himself as Eddie Brock, but definitely not enough to have to sit through another one of these films again.
reviews.author: Giovanni Lago

reviews.text:
Its wild, its messy, its meandering, sometimes its even boring but venom horse lives up to the hype + Eddie & Venom Bromance is the savior of this trilogy..

if you enjoy the others you will enjoy this
reviews.author: Zach Pope

reviews.text: As last dances go, it’s the Macarena in film form.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: I wanted to enjoy it more than I did but this film is a mess. The humor, Eddie/Venom dynamic, & Wild final battle will be enough of a good time for most just not me.
reviews.author: Cris Parker

reviews.text: Although this enjoyably capricious version of the character doesn’t quite resemble his vicious, violent comic counterpart, there’s a reason why Venom resonates with filmgoers—this spud wants to party and, when it counts, knows how to put on a good one.
reviews.author: Jarrod Jones

reviews.text: The film’s inability to find a single tone – comic, cathartic or otherwise – makes it feel like a failure on all fronts, and the constant intrusion of loud, obvious pop needle-drops don’t help.
reviews.author: Christina Newland

reviews.text: While Venom: The Last Dance does try to give an emotional goodbye to Eddie Brock and Venom's hilarious "bromance," too much of Tom Hardy's comedic charm is buried under Sony's unnecessary franchise setup.
reviews.author: Andrew J. Salazar

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance is an alien-invasion combined with a buddy road trip.
reviews.author: Michael Walsh

reviews.text: Despite some truly hysterical flashes of brilliance littered throughout, The Last Dance is a disappointingly grim farewell to the Venom franchise.
reviews.author: Hoai-Tran Bui

reviews.text: The Venom effects are still nicely rendered, but the punchlines are a little shopworn, although this franchise’s penchant for truly bonkers sequences has not diminished..
reviews.author: Tim Grierson

reviews.text: 'Venom: The Last Dance' is an outrageously fun and beautiful conclusion to a trilogy that we did not expect to go far.
reviews.author: Chalice Williams

reviews.text: Kelly Marcel triumphs in her feature film debut, incorporating music (as well as dance) to a greater degree than in the previous films in this trilogy.  Of course, Marcel's script (with story written with star Tom Hardy) leaves room for more Venom chaos.
reviews.author: Jana Monji

reviews.text: The Last Dance can't find its rhythm.
reviews.author: Olly Richards

reviews.text: It’s hard to say how these films will be remembered in the grand scheme of comic book history, but, with The Last Dance, we can at least be reminded that sometimes they actually managed to have fun with these things.
reviews.author: Clarisse Loughrey

reviews.text: Eventually the plot strands entwine for an extended beast-on-beast(s) climax that, like the finales of the first two movies, quickly devolves into a puddle of pixels that isn’t much fun to splash around in.
reviews.author: Jamie Graham

reviews.text: The Last Dance goes out with neither a bang nor a whimper, simply a farewell.
reviews.author: David Fear

reviews.text: Pleasant enough for fans, but no effort has been made here. Hardy is charming, Venom is funny and there are touching moments, but there's no point to the film whatsoever. Only worth watching if you need something to watch - and even then, for fans only.
reviews.author: Grace Randolph

reviews.text: If you're fully aboard the Venom train, then Venom: The Last Dance will prove to be the most entertaining of the trilogy – and it might even make you emotional.
reviews.author: Ian Sandwell

reviews.text: It’s not the best of its kind, but by no means the worst, and even when the inevitable war breaks out between humans, xenophages and symbiotes, Marcel orchestrates the action in a surprisingly comprehensible style...
reviews.author: Damon Wise

reviews.text: At least the film ends with a fittingly poignant/ridiculous tribute to the greatest love story ever told about a man and his symbiotic alien goo.
reviews.author: David Ehrlich

reviews.text: The most admirable thing about Venom: The Last Dance is that it tries. It really, really tries.
reviews.author: Germain Lussier

reviews.text: The more that The Last Dance leans into the idea of the bond between Eddie and Venom being a twisted romance, the funnier it is.
reviews.author: Liz Shannon Miller

reviews.text: This being the concluding chapter of a trilogy, it all leads to an emotional catharsis that will no doubt satisfy fans of the earlier movies, with a sweet touch of cheesy humor to offset the melancholy.
reviews.author: David Rooney

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance is therefore one-half of a wonderful movie. Still, it's worth sticking through the rest for a totally gonzo finale that's somehow equally absurd and moving.
reviews.author: Kristy Puchko

reviews.text: Watching “Venom: The Last Dance” is like watching the superhero genre die for two hours.
reviews.author: William Bibbiani

reviews.text: It’s a delightfully deranged dual performance by Hardy that doesn’t get enough credit in the greater comic-book movie canon, even if in this one the cartoonish violence is turned down in favor of forced sentimentality.
reviews.author: Brian Truitt

reviews.text: It’s quick and brash and seemingly aware of how goofy so much of it is but it’s also awkwardly overstuffed.
reviews.author: Benjamin Lee

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance is a disappointing Sony-Marvel release to go alongside Madame Web. And the odds for Kraven the Hunter to complete a single-year trifecta of Spider-Man spinoff misses are going way, way up.
reviews.author: Kofi Outlaw

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance trips over its own tendrils and lets a boring, generic plot, and bad action distract from the surprisingly resilient central relationship between Eddie Brock and his symbiote bestie.
reviews.author: Tom Jorgensen

reviews.text: The “Venom” movies are a lark and nothing more, geared to the arrested pleasure centers of fanboys: the more snark and CGI the better.
reviews.author: Owen Gleiberman

reviews.text: While the script is all over the place, there’s solid direction, with humor and drama rooted in sincerity. Whether it actually is the final curtain call for Hardy’s take... he’s at least going out with what may actually be 2024’s best comic book movie.
reviews.author: Aaron Neuwirth

reviews.text: Last Dance seems almost begging to solely be watched on airplanes, in the soporific 90 minutes between dinner service and uneasy, upright sleep. It functions best as an accidentally found object rather than something deliberately sought out.
reviews.author: Richard Lawson

reviews.text: This final entry in the Venom saga doesn’t feel like it’s even trying to be coherent and the result is unsurprisingly quite disappointing.
reviews.author: Abe Friedtanzer

reviews.text: "Venom: The Last Dance" is the closing chapter of an unlikely trilogy, a springboard for further IP mining, and a touching send-off to the hero some of us didn't even want but will now surely miss.
reviews.author: Dominic Griffin

reviews.text: Throws so many new elements at the franchise that it distracts from whatever scant parts of the first two that worked.
reviews.author: Fred Topel

reviews.text: Although Venom: The Last Dance doesn’t stoop to the embarrassing lows of this year’s earlier SSMU entry, Madame Web, it is a frustrating experience with just enough shining moments to make you realize how much more fun this should have been.
reviews.author: Sean Boelman

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance is a gloriously stupid capper to a ridiculous trilogy.
reviews.author: Joey Magidson

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance isn’t a lark, but a smirk to let you know that while everyone may be aware of what it’s up to, you’re the sucker who bought the ticket.
reviews.author: Alison Willmore

reviews.text: Very silly and sometimes flat out stupid, but it’s also intentionally goofy. The supporting cast is given little to do but Tom Hardy’s performance and the interplay between Eddie and Venom is still very enjoyable.
reviews.author: Eric Goldman

reviews.text: If this truly is the pair’s big-screen goodbye, at least it ends on a fittingly wacko note of pure, unadulterated sentimentality.
reviews.author: Nick Schager

reviews.text: If this really is "The Last Dance," it comes not a moment too soon.
reviews.author: Chris Evangelista

reviews.text: It feels like a collection of Tik-Tok videos, except even those show more imaginative storytelling than this $120 million dud.
reviews.author: Joonatan Itkonen

reviews.text: The action may be stellar, but Venom: The Last Dance continues the series' trend of failing to form a symbiotic relationship with its title character and its narrative.
reviews.author: Aidan Kelley

reviews.text: There’s maybe ten good minutes in a 95-minute movie.
reviews.author: Matt Singer

reviews.text: Kelly Marcel takes the reins in her directorial debut with the franchise's strongest effort, which, at its best, is pure punk rock comic book anarchy goodness, for better or worse.
reviews.author: M.N. Miller

reviews.text: Venom: The Last Dance is unintentionally hilarious, and many parts had me rolling my eyes. The friendship between Eddie Brock and Venom was fun. Sadly, the story, dialogue, and characters were mediocre.
reviews.author: John Nguyen

reviews.text: A highly entertaining film, offering a satisfying blend of thrills, humour, and emotion. While it doesn’t reinvent the superhero genre, it leans fully into what makes Venom unique: a wild, chaotic energy that refuses to play by the rules.
reviews.author: Linda Marric

reviews.text: The most cinematic, monumental Venom movie to date, The Last Dance leaves room for improvement but by upping the stakes and allowing Eddie and Venom to bond, it’s epic and heartfelt enough to leave us hoping this is far from Tom Hardy’s last whirl.
reviews.author: Josh Wilding

reviews.text: A futile third Venom movie that fails to give Tom Hardy's character a proper send-off.
reviews.author: Casey Chong

reviews.text: As the film progresses, it consistently escalates the stakes and scale of its action, which doesn’t devolve into incomprehensible CG murk as it hurtles toward the climax.
reviews.author: Jake Cole

reviews.text: In a whirlwind of chaotic creativity, Venom The Last Dance emerges as the most entertaining disaster of the trilogy, boldly embracing its bizarre charm. These films aren’t for me but it’ll leave its fans of the series amused by its peculiar tone.
reviews.author: Elliott Collins

reviews.text: “The Last Dance” brings nothing new to the series. In fact, it brings less than the previous two movies.
reviews.author: Soren Andersen

reviews.text: This movie could properly be titled, Venom: Things Happen.
reviews.author: Jeremy Jahns

synopsis: In Venom: The Last Dance, Tom Hardy returns as Venom, one of Marvel's greatest and most complex characters, for the final film in the trilogy. Eddie and Venom are on the run. Hunted by both of their worlds and with the net closing in, the duo are forced into a devastating decision that will bring the curtains down on Venom and Eddie's last dance.
